text: Yahweh’s word that came to Hosea the son of Beeri, in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Yahweh spoke at first by Hosea, Yahweh said to Hosea, “Go, take for yourself a wife of prostitution and children of unfaithfulness; for the land commits great adultery, forsaking Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went and took Gomer the daughter of Diblaim; and she conceived, and bore him a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said to him, “Call his name Jezreel, for yet a little while, and I will avenge the blood of Jezreel on the house of Jehu, and will cause the kingdom of the house of Israel to cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will happen in that day that I will break the bow of Israel in the valley of Jezreel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
She conceived again, and bore a daughter.
Then he said to him, “Call her name Lo-Ruhamah, for I will no longer have mercy on the house of Israel, that I should in any way pardon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will have mercy on the house of Judah, and will save them by Yahweh their God, and will not save them by bow, sword, battle, horses, or horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when she had weaned Lo-Ruhamah, she conceived, and bore a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Call his name Lo-Ammi, for you are not my people, and I will not be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the number of the children of Israel will be as the sand of the sea, which can’t be measured or counted; and it will come to pass that, in the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’ they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Judah and the children of Israel will be gathered together, and they will appoint themselves one head, and will go up from the land; for great will be the day of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Say to your brothers, ‘My people!’
    and to your sisters, ‘My loved one!’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
lest I strip her naked,
    and make her bare as in the day that she was born,
and make her like a wilderness,
    and set her like a dry land,
    and kill her with thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, on her children I will have no mercy,
    for they are children of unfaithfulness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore behold, I will hedge up your way with thorns,
    and I will build a wall against her,
    that she can’t find her way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will follow after her lovers,
    but she won’t overtake them;
and she will seek them,
    but won’t find them.
Then she will say, ‘I will go and return to my first husband,
    for then it was better with me than now.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
For she didn’t know that I gave her the grain, the new wine, and the oil,
    and multiplied to her silver and gold, which they used for Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I will take back my grain in its time,
    and my new wine in its season,
    and will pluck away my wool and my flax which should have covered her nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I will uncover her lewdness in the sight of her lovers,
    and no one will deliver her out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will also cause all her celebrations to cease:
    her feasts, her new moons, her Sabbaths, and all her solemn assemblies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will lay waste her vines and her fig trees,
    about which she has said, ‘These are my wages that my lovers have given me,’
    and I will make them a forest,
    and the animals of the field shall eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will visit on her the days of the Baals,
    to which she burned incense
when she decked herself with her earrings and her jewels,
    and went after her lovers
    and forgot me,” says Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore behold, I will allure her,
    and bring her into the wilderness,
    and speak tenderly to her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give her vineyards from there,
    and the valley of Achor for a door of hope;
and she will respond there
    as in the days of her youth,
    and as in the day when she came up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be in that day,” says Yahweh,
    “that you will call me ‘my husband,’
    and no longer call me ‘my master.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will take away the names of the Baals out of her mouth,
    and they will no longer be mentioned by name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day I will make a covenant for them with the animals of the field,
    and with the birds of the sky,
    and with the creeping things of the ground.
I will break the bow, the sword, and the battle out of the land,
    and will make them lie down safely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will betroth you to me forever.
    Yes, I will betroth you to me in righteousness, in justice, in loving kindness, and in compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will even betroth you to me in faithfulness;
    and you shall know Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
and the earth will respond to the grain, and the new wine, and the oil;
    and they will respond to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Yahweh said to me, “Go again, love a woman loved by another, and an adulteress, even as Yahweh loves the children of Israel, though they turn to other gods, and love cakes of raisins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I bought her for myself for fifteen pieces of silver and a homer and a half of barley.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to her, “You shall stay with me many days. You shall not play the prostitute, and you shall not be with any other man. I will also be so toward you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the children of Israel shall live many days without king, without prince, without sacrifice, without sacred stone, and without ephod or idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward the children of Israel shall return and seek Yahweh their God, and David their king, and shall come with trembling to Yahweh and to his blessings in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear Yahweh’s word, you children of Israel,
    for Yahweh has a charge against the inhabitants of the land:
“Indeed there is no truth, nor goodness,
    nor knowledge of God in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is cursing, lying, murder, stealing, and committing adultery;
    they break boundaries, and bloodshed causes bloodshed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the land will mourn,
    and everyone who dwells in it will waste away,
with all living things in her,
    even the animals of the field and the birds of the sky;
    yes, the fish of the sea also die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yet let no man bring a charge, neither let any man accuse;
    for your people are like those who bring charges against a priest.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge.
    Because you have rejected knowledge, I will also reject you,
    that you may be no priest to me.
Because you have forgotten your God’s law,
    I will also forget your children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As they were multiplied, so they sinned against me.
    I will change their glory into shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They feed on the sin of my people,
    and set their heart on their iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: Prostitution, wine, and new wine take away understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people consult with their wooden idol,
    and answer to a stick of wood.
Indeed the spirit of prostitution has led them astray,
    and they have been unfaithful to their God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sacrifice on the tops of the mountains,
    and burn incense on the hills, under oaks, poplars, and terebinths,
    because its shade is good.
Therefore your daughters play the prostitute,
    and your brides commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Though you, Israel, play the prostitute,
    yet don’t let Judah offend;
    and don’t come to Gilgal,
    neither go up to Beth Aven,
    nor swear, ‘As Yahweh lives.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Israel has behaved extremely stubbornly, like a stubborn heifer.
    Then how will Yahweh feed them like a lamb in a meadow?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim is joined to idols.
    Leave him alone!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their drink has become sour.
    They play the prostitute continually.
    Her rulers dearly love their shameful way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wind has wrapped her up in its wings;
    and they shall be disappointed because of their sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The rebels are deep in slaughter,
    but I discipline all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know Ephraim,
    and Israel is not hidden from me;
for now, Ephraim, you have played the prostitute.
    Israel is defiled.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The pride of Israel testifies to his face.
    Therefore Israel and Ephraim will stumble in their iniquity.
    Judah also will stumble with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will go with their flocks and with their herds to seek Yahweh,
    but they won’t find him.
    He has withdrawn himself from them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Blow the cornet in Gibeah,
    and the trumpet in Ramah!
    Sound a battle cry at Beth Aven, behind you, Benjamin!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim will become a desolation in the day of rebuke.
    Among the tribes of Israel, I have made known that which will surely be.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes of Judah are like those who remove a landmark.
    I will pour out my wrath on them like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim is oppressed,
    he is crushed in judgment,
    because he is intent in his pursuit of idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I am to Ephraim like a moth,
    and to the house of Judah like rottenness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When Ephraim saw his sickness,
    and Judah his wound,
    then Ephraim went to Assyria,
    and sent to King Jareb:
but he is not able to heal you,
    neither will he cure you of your wound.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will be to Ephraim like a lion,
    and like a young lion to the house of Judah.
I myself will tear in pieces and go away.
    I will carry off, and there will be no one to deliver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will go and return to my place,
    until they acknowledge their offense,
    and seek my face.
    In their affliction they will seek me earnestly.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
After two days he will revive us.
    On the third day he will raise us up,
    and we will live before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s acknowledge Yahweh.
    Let’s press on to know Yahweh.
As surely as the sun rises,
    Yahweh will appear.
He will come to us like the rain,
    like the spring rain that waters the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Ephraim, what shall I do to you?
    Judah, what shall I do to you?
    For your love is like a morning cloud,
    and like the dew that disappears early.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For I desire mercy, and not sacrifice;
    and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they, like Adam, have broken the covenant.
    They were unfaithful to me there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead is a city of those who work iniquity;
    it is stained with blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As gangs of robbers wait to ambush a man,
    so the company of priests murder on the path toward Shechem,
    committing shameful crimes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the house of Israel I have seen a horrible thing.
    There is prostitution in Ephraim.
    Israel is defiled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Also, Judah, there is a harvest appointed for you,
    when I restore the fortunes of my people.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They don’t consider in their hearts that I remember all their wickedness.
    Now their own deeds have engulfed them.
    They are before my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They make the king glad with their wickedness,
    and the princes with their lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all adulterers.
    They are burning like an oven that the baker stops stirring,
    from the kneading of the dough, until it is leavened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the day of our king, the princes made themselves sick with the heat of wine.
    He joined his hand with mockers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they have prepared their heart like an oven,
    while they lie in wait.
    Their anger smolders all night.
    In the morning it burns as a flaming fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all hot as an oven,
    and devour their judges.
All their kings have fallen.
    There is no one among them who calls to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim mixes himself among the nations.
    Ephraim is a pancake not turned over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strangers have devoured his strength,
    and he doesn’t realize it.
Indeed, gray hairs are here and there on him,
    and he doesn’t realize it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Ephraim is like an easily deceived dove, without understanding.
    They call to Egypt.
    They go to Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they go, I will spread my net on them.
    I will bring them down like the birds of the sky.
    I will chastise them, as their congregation has heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to them!
    For they have wandered from me.
Destruction to them!
    For they have trespassed against me.
Though I would redeem them,
    yet they have spoken lies against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They haven’t cried to me with their heart,
    but they howl on their beds.
They assemble themselves for grain and new wine.
    They turn away from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I have taught and strengthened their arms,
    yet they plot evil against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They return, but not to the Most High.
    They are like a faulty bow.
    Their princes will fall by the sword for the rage of their tongue.
    This will be their derision in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Put the trumpet to your lips!
    Something like an eagle is over Yahweh’s house,
    because they have broken my covenant
    and rebelled against my law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cry to me, ‘My God, we, Israel, acknowledge you!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel has cast off that which is good.
    The enemy will pursue him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have set up kings, but not by me.
    They have made princes, and I didn’t approve.
    Of their silver and their gold they have made themselves idols,
    that they may be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let Samaria throw out his calf idol!
    My anger burns against them!
    How long will it be until they are capable of purity?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For they sow the wind,
    and they will reap the whirlwind.
He has no standing grain.
    The stalk will yield no head.
    If it does yield, strangers will swallow it up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel is swallowed up.
    Now they are among the nations like a worthless thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they have gone up to Assyria,
    like a wild donkey wandering alone.
    Ephraim has hired lovers for himself.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because Ephraim has multiplied altars for sinning,
    they became for him altars for sinning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wrote for him the many things of my law,
    but they were regarded as a strange thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for the sacrifices of my offerings,
    they sacrifice meat and eat it,
    but Yahweh doesn’t accept them.
Now he will remember their iniquity,
    and punish their sins.
    They will return to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The threshing floor and the wine press won’t feed them,
    and the new wine will fail her.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
What will you do in the day of solemn assembly,
    and in the day of the feast of Yahweh?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For, behold, when they flee destruction,
    Egypt will gather them up.
    Memphis will bury them.
    Nettles will possess their pleasant things of silver.
    Thorns will be in their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The days of visitation have come.
    The days of reckoning have come.
Israel will consider the prophet to be a fool,
    and the man who is inspired to be insane,
    because of the abundance of your sins,
    and because your hostility is great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A prophet watches over Ephraim with my God.
    A fowler’s snare is on all of his paths,
    and hostility in the house of his God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have deeply corrupted themselves,
    as in the days of Gibeah.
    He will remember their iniquity.
    He will punish them for their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I found Israel like grapes in the wilderness.
    I saw your fathers as the first ripe in the fig tree at its first season;
    but they came to Baal Peor, and consecrated themselves to the shameful thing,
    and became abominable like that which they loved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for Ephraim, their glory will fly away like a bird.
    There will be no birth, no one with child, and no conception.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though they bring up their children,
    yet I will bereave them, so that not a man shall be left.
    Indeed, woe also to them when I depart from them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen Ephraim, like Tyre, planted in a pleasant place;
    but Ephraim will bring out his children to the murderer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give them—Yahweh what will you give?
    Give them a miscarrying womb and dry breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“All their wickedness is in Gilgal;
    for there I hated them.
    Because of the wickedness of their deeds, I will drive them out of my house!
    I will love them no more.
    All their princes are rebels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim is struck.
    Their root has dried up.
    They will bear no fruit.
    Even though they give birth, yet I will kill the beloved ones of their womb.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My God will cast them away, because they didn’t listen to him;
    and they will be wanderers among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel is a luxuriant vine that produces his fruit.
    According to the abundance of his fruit he has multiplied his altars.
    As their land has prospered, they have adorned their sacred stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their heart is divided.
    Now they will be found guilty.
    He will demolish their altars.
    He will destroy their sacred stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely now they will say, “We have no king; for we don’t fear Yahweh;
    and the king, what can he do for us?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They make promises, swearing falsely in making covenants.
    Therefore judgment springs up like poisonous weeds in the furrows of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The inhabitants of Samaria will be in terror for the calves of Beth Aven,
    for its people will mourn over it,
    along with its priests who rejoiced over it,
    for its glory, because it has departed from it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It also will be carried to Assyria for a present to a great king.
    Ephraim will receive shame,
    and Israel will be ashamed of his own counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samaria and her king float away
    like a twig on the water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The high places also of Aven, the sin of Israel, will be destroyed.
    The thorn and the thistle will come up on their altars.
    They will tell the mountains, “Cover us!” and the hills, “Fall on us!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Israel, you have sinned from the days of Gibeah.
    There they remained.
    The battle against the children of iniquity doesn’t overtake them in Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Ephraim is a trained heifer that loves to thresh,
    so I will put a yoke on her beautiful neck.
    I will set a rider on Ephraim.
    Judah will plow.
    Jacob will break his clods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sow to yourselves in righteousness,
    reap according to kindness.
Break up your fallow ground,
    for it is time to seek Yahweh,
    until he comes and rains righteousness on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have plowed wickedness.
    You have reaped iniquity.
    You have eaten the fruit of lies,
    for you trusted in your way, in the multitude of your mighty men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore a battle roar will arise among your people,
    and all your fortresses will be destroyed,
    as Shalman destroyed Beth Arbel in the day of battle.
    The mother was dashed in pieces with her children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Bethel will do to you because of your great wickedness.
    At daybreak the king of Israel will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When Israel was a child, then I loved him,
    and called my son out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They called to them, so they went from them.
    They sacrificed to the Baals,
    and burned incense to engraved images.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet I taught Ephraim to walk.
    I took them by their arms,
    but they didn’t know that I healed them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The sword will fall on their cities,
    and will destroy the bars of their gates,
    and will put an end to their plans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My people are determined to turn from me.
    Though they call to the Most High,
    he certainly won’t exalt them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How can I give you up, Ephraim?
    How can I hand you over, Israel?
    How can I make you like Admah?
    How can I make you like Zeboiim?
My heart is turned within me,
    my compassion is aroused.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not execute the fierceness of my anger.
    I will not return to destroy Ephraim,
    for I am God, and not man—the Holy One among you.
    I will not come in wrath.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Ephraim surrounds me with falsehood,
    and the house of Israel with deceit.
    Judah still strays from God,
    and is unfaithful to the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim feeds on wind,
    and chases the east wind.
    He continually multiplies lies and desolation.
    They make a covenant with Assyria,
    and oil is carried into Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In the womb he took his brother by the heel,
    and in his manhood he contended with God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
even Yahweh, the God of Armies.
    Yahweh is his name of renown!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore turn to your God.
    Keep kindness and justice,
    and wait continually for your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A merchant has dishonest scales in his hand.
    He loves to defraud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim said, “Surely I have become rich.
    I have found myself wealth.
    In all my wealth they won’t find in me any iniquity that is sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But I am Yahweh your God from the land of Egypt.
    I will yet again make you dwell in tents,
    as in the days of the solemn feast.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
If Gilead is wicked,
    surely they are worthless.
In Gilgal they sacrifice bulls.
    Indeed, their altars are like heaps in the furrows of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob fled into the country of Aram.
    Israel served to get a wife.
    For a wife he tended flocks and herds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By a prophet Yahweh brought Israel up out of Egypt,
    and by a prophet he was preserved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim has bitterly provoked anger.
    Therefore his blood will be left on him,
    and his Lord will repay his contempt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Ephraim spoke, there was trembling.
    He exalted himself in Israel,
    but when he became guilty through Baal, he died.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now they sin more and more,
    and have made themselves molten images of their silver,
    even idols according to their own understanding,
    all of them the work of the craftsmen.
    They say of them, ‘They offer human sacrifice and kiss the calves.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they will be like the morning mist,
    like the dew that passes away early,
    like the chaff that is driven with the whirlwind out of the threshing floor,
    and like the smoke out of the chimney.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I knew you in the wilderness,
    in the land of great drought.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore I am like a lion to them.
    Like a leopard, I will lurk by the path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will meet them like a bear that is bereaved of her cubs,
    and will tear the covering of their heart.
    There I will devour them like a lioness.
    The wild animal will tear them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are destroyed, Israel, because you are against me,
    against your helper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where is your king now, that he may save you in all your cities?
    And your judges, of whom you said, ‘Give me a king and princes’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have given you a king in my anger,
    and have taken him away in my wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The guilt of Ephraim is stored up.
    His sin is stored up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sorrows of a travailing woman will come on him.
    He is an unwise son,
    for when it is time, he doesn’t come to the opening of the womb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will ransom them from the power of Sheol.
    I will redeem them from death!
    Death, where are your plagues?
    Sheol, where is your destruction? 
“Compassion will be hidden from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he is fruitful among his brothers, an east wind will come,
    the breath of Yahweh coming up from the wilderness;
    and his spring will become dry,
    and his fountain will be dried up.
    He will plunder the storehouse of treasure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Samaria will bear her guilt,
    for she has rebelled against her God.
    They will fall by the sword.
    Their infants will be dashed in pieces,
    and their pregnant women will be ripped open.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel, return to Yahweh your God;
    for you have fallen because of your sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take words with you, and return to Yahweh.
    Tell him, “Forgive all our sins,
    and accept that which is good;
    so we offer bulls as we vowed of our lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Assyria can’t save us.
    We won’t ride on horses;
    neither will we say any more to the work of our hands, ‘Our gods!’
    for in you the fatherless finds mercy.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will be like the dew to Israel.
    He will blossom like the lily,
    and send down his roots like Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His branches will spread,
    and his beauty will be like the olive tree,
    and his fragrance like Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men will dwell in his shade.
    They will revive like the grain,
    and blossom like the vine.
    Their fragrance will be like the wine of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ephraim, what have I to do any more with idols?
    I answer, and will take care of him.
    I am like a green cypress tree;
    from me your fruit is found.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is wise, that he may understand these things?
    Who is prudent, that he may know them?
    For the ways of Yahweh are right,
    and the righteous walk in them,
    but the rebellious stumble in them.
speaker: Narrator
